semantic_title: Selection of Principal Diagnosis - UHDDS Definition and Fundamental Principles
section_path: Section II > Selection of Principal Diagnosis

content.full_text: The circumstances of inpatient admission always govern the selection of principal diagnosis. The principal diagnosis is defined in the Uniform Hospital Discharge Data Set (UHDDS) as 'that condition established after study to be chiefly responsible for occasioning the admission of the patient to the hospital for care.' The UHDDS definitions are used by hospitals to report inpatient data elements in a standardized manner. These data elements and their definitions can be found in the July 31, 1985, Federal Register (Vol. 50, No, 147), pp. 31038-40. Since that time, the application of the UHDDS definitions has been expanded to include all non-outpatient settings (acute care, short term, long term care and psychiatric hospitals; home health agencies; rehab facilities; nursing homes, etc.). The UHDDS definitions also apply to hospice services (all levels of care). (Evidence: pg no: 108, L90-L96)
content.summary: Fundamental definition and scope of principal diagnosis selection based on UHDDS standards, applicable to all non-outpatient healthcare settings (Evidence: pg no: 108, L90-L96)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Principal diagnosis is that condition established after study to be chiefly responsible for occasioning the admission (Evidence: pg no: 108, L91)
detailed_rules.explanation: The principal diagnosis must be determined through clinical study and represent the primary reason for the patient's admission to the hospital (Evidence: pg no: 108, L91)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Circumstances of inpatient admission always govern principal diagnosis selection (Evidence: pg no: 108, L90-L91)
detailed_rules.explanation: The specific circumstances that led to the patient's admission must be the primary consideration in selecting the principal diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 108, L90-L91)

detailed_rules.rule_text: UHDDS definitions apply to all non-outpatient settings including hospice services (Evidence: pg no: 108, L95-L96)
detailed_rules.explanation: The scope includes acute care, short term, long term care, psychiatric hospitals, home health agencies, rehab facilities, nursing homes, and hospice services (Evidence: pg no: 108, L95-L96)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Review circumstances of inpatient admission
Step 2: Identify all conditions present during admission
Step 3: Determine which condition was chiefly responsible for admission after study
Step 4: Select that condition as principal diagnosis
Step 5: Apply to appropriate non-outpatient setting

coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient presented to ED with chest pain. After study including EKG and cardiac enzymes, diagnosed with acute myocardial infarction. Admitted for treatment.
step_by_step: Step 1: Review admission circumstances (chest pain presentation)
Step 2: Identify condition established after study (myocardial infarction)
Step 3: Determine chief reason for admission (myocardial infarction)
